Introduction to Home Care

  • April 20, 2015
  • /
  • Getting started
  • /
  • No Comments

If we had the opportunity many people would likely decide that they would stay in their home for their entire lives. But with age this outcome will be dependent upon one’s ability to find affordable and reliable home care. Changes to your home may also be needed, things such as stair lifts and bathroom handrails.

But to be able to make claims for cash to pay for these things the local authority will make an assessment of you and your finances.

This begs the question, who pays for this? The answer is, it depends upon your care and financial needs whom pays. On some occasions you will be entitled to partial or full payment from your local authority. Most of the time however, you will be expected to fund these things completely on your own, such as if you are wealthy or in relatively good health for your age or both.

If you happen to be funding your home care you are able to pick whom your home care provider gets to be. The options vary but you can contact an agency to help you with your requirements. Also, if you are receiving complete or partial funding your local authority you will often be able to get direct payments which means you can still pick who your provider gets to be.

The assessments which the authority takes are not unwavering, that is, if your financial situation changes drastically, you may be reassessed.

So what are the costs you might then need to expect to pay? Costs require vary heavily with the region you happen to live in. Cost will depend on what kind of care and assistance you might require, how many hours, time of day and those kinds of things.

Cost is indeed important but the quality and reliability of the service provided is also important as well. Either read more by visiting our article on the costs of home care, or take the assessment to see what care providers are in your area and how they can help.
